image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Warren Mundine speak at a meeting. Mr Mundine has his arm out gesturing.

items.synopsis: The two campaigns pushing for a No vote to the forthcoming Voice to Parliament referendum merge, in a move that aims to unify their message and strengthen their campaign.

title.children: Key 'No' Voice camps merge to strengthen referendum campaign

image.altText: A Sydney tram with emergency workers alongside

items.synopsis: Emergency services worked to free the 16-year-old, who had critical injuries, but she died at the scene.

title.children: Teenage girl dies after becoming trapped under light rail tram in Sydney CBD

image.altText: Dr Rose

items.synopsis: Rose McGready's world-renowned research could save your life if you contract malaria. But the unassuming Australian doctor now needs to raise enough money to keep her life-saving clinics afloat.

title.children: Australian doctor who's saved thousands of lives on the frontline faces toughest challenge yet

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2023-24 federal budget strategy and outlook book in front of the media

items.synopsis: We now know what the government thinks it will cost to futureproof the NDIS — a whopping $74 billion in savings over the next decade. So why didn't the treasurer cite this impressive number in his budget speech, writes David Speers.

title.children: The whopping $74b budget saving that Chalmers kept quiet

image.altText: A piece of land with the Australian flag and the Chinese flag next to each other with a big crack separating the two

items.synopsis: Australia's Trade Minister Don Farrell will hold a meeting with his Chinese counterpart in Beijing this week, with hopes it could signal the trade turmoil between China and Australia will soon be over.

title.children: Could Trade Minister Don Farrell's visit to Beijing bring about an end to trade bans on Australian goods?

image.altText: Prince Harry with a beard and furrowed brow wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: A British tabloid newspaper apologises to Prince Harry for unlawfully seeking information about him at the start of the royal's lawsuit against its publisher over alleged phone hacking, in which he is due to give evidence himself.

title.children: 'Blatantly unlawful': British tabloid apologises to Prince Harry

image.altText: A woman wearing blue scrubs has her arm around an older woman wearing a pink cardigan as they walk across a lush green lawn.

items.synopsis: Older Australians are increasingly opting to receive care at home, rather than in residential aged care, a shift that the federal government projects will save billions of dollars.

title.children: After 'five years of aged scare', a decline in residential aged care could deliver big budget savings

image.altText: Composite of AFP journalist Arman Soldin cyclist Kaden Groves.

items.synopsis: The news Australia is searching for, and all the news that happened while you snoozed: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: France investigates death of journalist in Ukraine, young Australian's racing win, and girl dies after tram collision. Catch up with The Loop

schema.headline: Live updates: France investigates death of journalist in Ukraine, young Australian's racing win, and girl dies after tram collision

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Outgoing Finnish PM Sanna Marin and husband file for divorce
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Finland's outgoing Prime Minister Sanna Marin has filed for divorce jointly with her husband of three years Markus Raikkonen, they have announced on Instagram. "We are grateful for the 19 years together and our beloved daughter. We will remain best friends," they said in separate Instagram stories. The pair share a 5-year-old daughter and got married in 2020 while Marin was in office dealing with the impact of the pandemic. Marin and her Social Democratic Party lost Finland's election for parliament last month, trailing the right-wing National Coalition Party as well as the nationalist Finns Party. Marin, 37, the world's youngest prime minister when she took office in 2019, is considered by fans around the globe as a millennial role model for progressive new leaders, even as voters at home opted for a new government.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The NRL says Canberra's stadium is no longer fit for purpose
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The National Rugby League has weighed into the debate over a new stadium for Canberra - saying its long overdue. The NRL has made a submission to the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital. The NRL says Canberra has lost its appeal as a potential location for rugby league events of national significance. It says Canberra's stadium is no longer fit for purpose and will be overlooked in favour of other venues like the new Townsville Stadium.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Britain ditches commitment to replace all EU laws by the end of 2023
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The British government has ditched its plan for thousands of EU-era laws to expire automatically at the end of the year. The plan — dubbed a post-Brexit 'bonfire' — would see laws that were copied over to the UK after Brexit vanish, unless specifically kept or replaced. Critics of the bill had voiced concerns that it could lead to important legislation falling away by accident. The backdown is likely to trigger anger from Brexit-backing Conservative MPs.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The Daily Mirror has apologised to Prince Harry
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The British tabloid newspaper apologised for unlawfully seeking information about the royal. It comes at the start of Prince Harry's lawsuit against the newspaper's publisher over alleged phone hacking, in which he is due to give evidence himself. Harry, 38, and about 100 celebrities, are suing publisher Mirror Group Newspapers, accusing its titles of habitually accessing private information by widespread phone hacking, deception and other illicit means between 1991 and 2011. You can read more about the case here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: France is investigating the death of a journalist in Ukraine
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: French authorities have launched an investigation into possible war crimes over the death of a French journalist in Ukraine. Arman Soldin, a video journalist with AFP news agency, was killed by rocket fire near Chasiv Yar in eastern Ukraine earlier this week. Russian forces have been frequently bombing the town over recent weeks. French prosecutors say the investigation will try to establish the exact circumstances of Mr Soldin's death.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: A young Australian has won the fifth stage of an Italian cycling race
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Kaden Groves has overcome a late crash to give Australia another success at cycling's Giro d'Italia. The 24-year old Queenslander came down with several other riders in wet conditions with 7km remaining of the fifth stage, but amazingly recovered in time to prevail in a sprint finish. It was his second Grand Tour win after claiming a stage during last year's Tour of Spain, and came just two days after Canberra's Michael Matthews took out stage 3 in Italy. Race favourite Remco Evenepoel of Belgium crashed twice on a day marred by dreadful weather, the first time after a dog strayed on to the road.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: A girl has died after a collision with a tram in Sydney
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The pedestrian died after being trapped under the tram in Sydney's CBD overnight. Emergency services were called to the Haymarket light rail station at around midnight after reports of a collision between a girl and a tram. They arrived to find the girl, believed to be in her teens, with critical injuries and she died at the scene.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: One more thing
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Fine arts students in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria are welcoming summer with some creative competition. They've gone head-to-head with their professors in the Sand Sculpture Festival. The event aims to attract visitors to the city's beaches over the warmer months.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live updates: France investigates death of journalist in Ukraine, young Australian's racing win, and girl dies after tram collision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning. It's Thursday, May 11 and I'm bringing back The Loop! Here's a bit of what's happening (click the link to jump to the post): France is investigating the death of a journalist in Ukraine A girl has died after a collision with a tram in Sydney A young Australian has won the fifth stage of an Italian cycling race The Daily Mirror has apologised to Prince Harry
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Let's set you up for the day

children.content: Good morning.

France is investigating the death of a journalist in Ukraine
A girl has died after a collision with a tram in Sydney
A young Australian has won the fifth stage of an Italian cycling race
The Daily Mirror has apologised to Prince Harry

The pair share a 5-year-old daughter and got married in 2020 while Marin was in office dealing with the impact of the pandemic. Marin and her Social Democratic Party lost Finland's election for parliament last month, trailing the right-wing National Coalition Party as well as the nationalist Finns Party. Marin, 37, the world's youngest prime minister when she took office in 2019, is considered by fans around the globe as a millennial role model for progressive new leaders, even as voters at home opted for a new government.

The NRL has made a submission to the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital. liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The British government has ditched its plan for thousands of EU-era laws to expire automatically at the end of the year. The plan — dubbed a post-Brexit 'bonfire' — would see laws that were copied over to the UK after Brexit vanish, unless specifically kept or replaced. Critics of the bill had voiced concerns that it could lead to important legislation falling away by accident. The backdown is likely to trigger anger from Brexit-backing Conservative MPs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Britain ditches commitment to replace all EU laws by the end of 2023

props.alt: The union jack and EU flag wave in the air with Big Ben seen in the background.

children.content: (Reuters: Tolga Akmen)
The British government has ditched its plan for thousands of EU-era laws to expire automatically at the end of the year.
The plan — dubbed a post-Brexit 'bonfire' — would see laws that were copied over to the UK after Brexit vanish, unless specifically kept or replaced.
Critics of the bill had voiced concerns that it could lead to important legislation falling away by accident.
The backdown is likely to trigger anger from Brexit-backing Conservative MPs.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The British tabloid newspaper apologised for unlawfully seeking information about the royal. It comes at the start of Prince Harry's lawsuit against the newspaper's publisher over alleged phone hacking, in which he is due to give evidence himself. Harry, 38, and about 100 celebrities, are suing publisher Mirror Group Newspapers, accusing its titles of habitually accessing private information by widespread phone hacking, deception and other illicit means between 1991 and 2011. image.altText: A coal load loads coal onto a large ship

items.synopsis: Economists and energy experts say the government is short-changing Australians with planned changes to the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax that will only raise an additional $2.4 billion over five years.

title.children: 'They screwed up': Economists say the PRRT is broken and the budget doesn't really fix it

image.altText: A middle-aged woman looks at the camera, standing in front of a sandstone wall

items.synopsis: A group of people whose families profited from slavery is trying to make amends for past wrongs.

title.children: Laura Trevelyan's ancestors owned slaves, so she decided to pay reparations

image.altText: A Ukrainian serviceman waves from a tank, as Russia's attack on Ukraine continues.

items.synopsis: A Ukrainian military unit says it has routed a Russian infantry brigade from frontline territory near Bakhmut, confirming an account by the head of Russia's Wagner Group that the Russian forces have fled.

title.children: 'Retreated': Ukraine and Wagner confirm Russian troops failing in Bakhmut

image.altText: Screenshots from the Bluesky app

items.synopsis: A new Twitter rival has emerged, backed by Twitter's co-founder and armed with an invitation-only viral marketing campaign. Will it work?

title.children: Will Bluesky replace Twitter? That may be only the start, with a plan to reshape social media

image.altText: A woman in an Imran Khan face mask, sunglasses and a headscarf raises an arm

items.synopsis: Pakistan's political crisis has worsened, stoking divisions in society, leading to extreme polarisation and the violent reactions we've seen this week, writes Zahid Shahab Ahmed.

title.children: Why Pakistan is on a knife edge — and fiery protests are expected to get worse

image.altText: A man in a face mask running past a burning car.

items.synopsis: A Pakistani court indicts former prime minister Imran Khan on charges of selling state gifts during his four years in power, a day after his arrest in an unrelated fraud case sparked unrest that killed at least five people.

title.children: Pakistan calls in army to quell deadly protests after former PM Imran Khan charged

image.altText: A young blonde girl smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: Fourteen-year-old Shyanne-Lee Tatnell has not been seen or heard from since April 30. Now community members are getting involved in the search to find her.

title.children: Search ramps up for Tasmanian teenager missing for 10 days

image.altText: A man wearing a blue shirt and hat sits on a macadamia machine harvesting nuts.

items.synopsis: The majority of Australian macadamia processors will pay their suppliers some of the lowest prices on record, with concerns they could drop further.

title.children: Macadamia growers face financial disaster as glut drives prices down

image.altText: Man in diving gear touching the mouth of a large whale shark underwater.

items.synopsis: Making a natural history documentary is a test of patience and endurance, and Tim Winton had finally run out of both. He was trying to capture the wild beauty of his beloved Ningaloo Reef but Mother Nature wouldn't play ball.

title.children: Tim Winton picked parasites off whale shark's mouth, but that's not what 'terrified' him

image.altText: Two men pass that says "Lismore Courthouse". One holds a notepad over his face. The other is long-haired and bearded.

items.synopsis: The NSW Coroner's Court is told that the organiser of the Dreaming Arts Festival played guitar while Jarrad Antonovich lay dying and later described his death as a "beautiful occasion".

title.children: Man's death from kambo frog poison described as 'beautiful occasion' as his mother weeps in court

image.altText: Close-up shot of Scales of Justice statue in Brisbane CBD on August 1, 2018.

items.synopsis: A Lake Macquarie man has pleaded guilty to seven domestic violence offences after a GPS tracking device was removed from his ex-lover's car and police found a listening device in her bedroom.

title.children: NSW man pleads guilty to bugging ex-lover's bedroom and tracking her car

image.altText: A dark-haired woman looks at her young daughter, who's facing her in a swing

items.synopsis: Tasmanians are waiting years instead of days to access vital ear, nose and throat specialist appointments. The Department of Health is trying to find a solution.

title.children: 'She can't sleep properly, can't eat properly': Seven year-old Stacey* has been waiting years to get her tonsils out

image.altText: A young boy in navy sitting in his wheelchair on the concrete edge of Brennan Park.

items.synopsis: One-fifth of the region is living with a disability, so why would a community park makeover leave some unable to play? This seven-year-old who uses a wheelchair is asking council to reconsider.

title.children: Zach loved playing in Brennan Park until council upgraded it, leaving him on the outer

image.altText: An Australian progressive metal group pose for the camera in a corridor backstage at the venue for the Eurovision Song Contest.

items.synopsis: Perth progressive metal band Voyager are finally achieving their dream to make Eurovision history, as the first group to represent Australia — they talk to ABC about the long road to the Contest, the songs that didn't quite make it, their Spinal Tap moment in Amsterdam, and more.

title.children: From Runaway to Dreamer to Promise, how Voyager finally made it to Eurovision

image.altText: Alexander Skarsgård, a white man with blonde hair is wearing sunglasses and a white striped shirt. He has cuts on his face.

items.synopsis: Following in his filmmaker father’s footsteps and riffing off the success of White Lotus and Triangle of Sadness, Brandon Cronenberg has made a stomach-churning holiday horror with Infinity Pool.

title.children: Alexander Skarsgård gets led around on a leash in this deranged-but-sexy sci-fi horror

image.altText: Five images of an Indigenous artwork being painted.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory arts minister is calling for a national investigation into allegations of interference by white assistants that are creating "reputational damage" to the Indigenous art industry.

title.children: 'Horrified' arts minister calls for national probe into 'damaging' Indigenous art claims, puts galleries on notice

image.altText: Four people including then prime minister Malcolm Turnbull look at a model of a navy boat

items.synopsis: Australia's troubled $45 billion project to build future frigates is facing a significant blow-out, with the auditor-general slamming Defence for failing to properly consider value for money during the tender process.

title.children: Auditor's scathing assessment of $45b future frigates program

image.altText: An electricity bill hangs on a silver fridge.

items.synopsis: The federal government had to negotiate different agreements with each state and territory, so it's a little complicated. Let's look at how much you might get slashed off your bill, depending on where you live.

title.children: Find out if you're eligible for the government's $500 energy bill relief payment with this state-by-state breakdown

image.altText: Mr Santos walks as reporters hold microphones up towards him.

items.synopsis: New York republican George Santos, infamous for fabricating key parts of his life story, has been arrested on federal criminal charges.

title.children: US Republican George Santos arrested on federal criminal charges

image.altText: a young man looking away from the camera. his face cannot be identified

items.synopsis: Teen brothers were found locked in their room, naked and in soiled nappies, after their father was discovered dead from a terminal illness at their home in Brisbane's northern suburbs.

title.children: Child safety officers saw teen gnawing on dog bone but failed to remove him from father's care

image.altText: Hussein I'lachi wearing a maroon and white jacket staring directly into the camera.

items.synopsis: The 21-year-old student says he went to the Carina Police Station in February to pay a parking fine, but was soon surrounded by six officers. He's since appeared in court four times under another man's name.

title.children: Queensland police arrested Hussein for hacking a university in 2013 — he would have been 12 years old

image.altText: A seahorse drifting through the murky depths.

items.synopsis: White's seahorse used to be a common sight in the waters off Sydney and Newcastle, but numbers have declined dramatically over the past 20 years. Scientists hope that might be starting to change.

title.children: Hundreds of endangered seahorses released into the wild off NSW coast

image.altText: A close up of Trump speaking in a heritage building. He is wearing a dark suit and a red tie over his white shirt.

items.synopsis: America has found itself in a surreal situation over the past two weeks as the former Elle magazine advice columnist E Jean Carroll has taken Donald Trump to a civil court in New York over an alleged sexual assault in the 1990s.

title.children: Trump's most loyal supporters will stick by him, but experts say he should brace for impact anyway

image.altText: Frankston serial killer questioned over alleged rape

items.synopsis: Paul Denyer, who murdered Melbourne women Natalie Russell, Elizabeth Stevens and Debbie Fream in the early 1990s, has been denied parole.

title.children: Parole board knocks back sadistic Frankston serial killer Paul Denyer's bid for freedom

image.altText: Two women in dresses and hats stand in a cotton field

items.synopsis: A region renowned for its golden sunflowers has a new drawcard that's raking in tourists, social media snaps — and dollars.

title.children: Move over sunflowers, there's a new crop ready to take over your Insta feed
